extracted_concepts.definition: Any ground or area that impedes a creature's movement, requiring extra effort or time to traverse.

rule_logic.premise: A creature moves into or through an area designated as difficult terrain
rule_logic.implication: Each foot of movement costs 2 feet instead of 1 foot
rule_logic.description_text: Every foot of movement in difficult terrain costs 1 extra foot. This rule is true even if multiple things in an area create difficult terrain. If an area contains two types of difficult terrain, for example, it doesn't cost 4 feet per 1 foot moved, only 3 feet.

extracted_concepts.definition: An area of light that creates a lightly obscured effect, such as twilight, moonlight, or flickering torches.

rule_logic.premise: A creature attempts to perceive something in an area of dim light
rule_logic.implication: The area is lightly obscured, and creatures have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight
rule_logic.description_text: Dim light, also called shadows, creates a lightly obscured area. An area of dim light has a perceptible boundary between it and a brightly lit area or total darkness. A creature in a lightly obscured area has disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

extracted_concepts.definition: The complete absence of light, creating a heavily obscured area.

rule_logic.premise: A creature attempts to perceive something in an area of darkness
rule_logic.implication: The area is heavily obscured, and creatures effectively suffer from the blinded condition
rule_logic.description_text: Darkness creates a heavily obscured area. Creatures in a heavily obscured area effectively suffer from the blinded condition.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition where an area is so heavily obscured that vision is impossible, such as darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage.

rule_logic.premise: An area is heavily obscured
rule_logic.implication: Creatures within or attempting to see into the area are effectively blinded
rule_logic.description_text: A heavily obscured area--such as darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage--blocks vision entirely. A creature in a heavily obscured area effectively suffers from the blinded condition.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage incurred by a creature when falling from a significant height, calculated based on the distance fallen.

rule_logic.premise: A creature falls from a height
rule_logic.implication: Creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet fallen
rule_logic.description_text: At the end of a fall, a creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition a creature assumes upon landing after a fall, unless specific criteria are met.

rule_logic.premise: A creature falls and lands
rule_logic.implication: Creature lands prone
exceptions: IF creature avoids taking damage from the fall
rule_logic.description_text: The creature lands prone, unless it avoids taking damage from the fall.
related_search_terms: do I land prone from fall

extracted_concepts.definition: The upper limit of bludgeoning damage a creature can take from a single fall, regardless of the height fallen.

rule_logic.premise: A creature takes damage from falling
rule_logic.implication: Damage taken from falling is capped at 20d6 bludgeoning damage
rule_logic.description_text: A creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6.

extracted_concepts.definition: The maximum amount of time a creature can actively hold its breath before it begins to suffocate.

rule_logic.premise: A creature is holding its breath
rule_logic.implication: Duration for holding breath is (1 + Constitution modifier) minutes, with a minimum duration of 30 seconds
rule_logic.description_text: A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds).
related_search_terms: how long can I hold breath

extracted_concepts.definition: The state and consequences a creature faces after it has run out of breath or is choking.

rule_logic.premise: A creature runs out of breath OR a creature is choking
rule_logic.implication: Creature can survive for (Constitution modifier) rounds (minimum of 1 round) before consequences occur. THEN at the start of its next turn after this duration, it drops to 0 hit points, is dying, AND cannot regain hit points OR be stabilized until it can breathe again.
rule_logic.description_text: When a creature runs out of breath or is choking, it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 round). At the start of its next turn, it drops to 0 hit points and is dying, and it can't regain hit points or be stabilized until it can breathe again.

extracted_concepts.definition: An area where vision is partially hindered, such as dim light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage.

rule_logic.premise: Creature is in a lightly obscured area
rule_logic.implication: Creature has disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight
rule_logic.description_text: In a lightly obscured area, such as dim light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage, creatures have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

extracted_concepts.definition: An area where vision is entirely blocked, such as darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage.

rule_logic.premise: Creature is in a heavily obscured area
rule_logic.implication: Creature effectively suffers from the blinded condition
rule_logic.description_text: A heavily obscured area-such as darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage-blocks vision entirely. A creature effectively suffers from the blinded condition (see appendix PH-A) when trying to see something in that area.

extracted_concepts.definition: An illumination category where most creatures can see normally, including daylight and strong light sources.

rule_logic.premise: Creature is in an area of bright light
rule_logic.implication: Creature sees normally
rule_logic.description_text: Bright light lets most creatures see normally. Even gloomy days provide bright light, as do torches, lanterns, fires, and other sources of illumination within a specific radius.

extracted_concepts.definition: An illumination category also called shadows, typically a boundary between bright light and darkness, or weak natural light.

rule_logic.premise: An area is considered dim light
rule_logic.implication: The area creates a lightly obscured area
rule_logic.description_text: Dim light, also called shadows, creates a lightly obscured area. An area of dim light is usually a boundary between a source of bright light, such as a torch, and surrounding darkness. The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as dim light. A particularly brilliant full moon might bathe the land in dim light.

extracted_concepts.definition: An illumination category representing the complete absence of light.

rule_logic.premise: An area is considered darkness
rule_logic.implication: The area creates a heavily obscured area
rule_logic.description_text: Darkness creates a heavily obscured area. Characters face darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit dungeon or a subterranean vault, or in an area of magical darkness.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special sense that allows a creature to perceive its surroundings without relying on sight within a specific radius.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has blindsight within a specific radius
rule_logic.implication: Creature can perceive its surroundings without relying on sight within that radius
rule_logic.description_text: A creature with blindsight can perceive its surroundings without relying on sight, within a specific radius. Creatures without eyes, such as oozes, and creatures with echolocation or heightened senses, such as bats and true dragons, have this sense.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special sense allowing a creature to see in darkness as if it were dim light, within a specified range.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has darkvision within a specified range AND is in an area of darkness
rule_logic.implication: Within that range, the creature sees darkness as dim light (meaning the area is only lightly obscured for them). The creature cannot discern color, only shades of gray.
rule_logic.description_text: Within a specified range, a creature with darkvision can see in darkness as if the darkness were dim light, so areas of darkness are only lightly obscured as far as that creature is concerned. However, the creature can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

extracted_concepts.definition: A superior special sense allowing a creature to see beyond normal and magical obscurations, and perceive hidden truths.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has truesight within a specific range
rule_logic.implication: Within that range, the creature can: see in normal and magical darkness; see invisible creatures and objects; automatically detect visual illusions and succeed on saving throws against them; perceive the original form of a shapechanger or a creature transformed by magic; and see into the Ethereal Plane
rule_logic.description_text: A creature with truesight can, out to a specific range, see in normal and magical darkness, see invisible creatures and objects, automatically detect visual illusions and succeed on saving throws against them, and perceives the original form of a shapechanger or a creature that is transformed by magic. Furthermore, the creature can see into the Ethereal Plane.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition suffered by characters who fail to consume the required daily amounts of food or water.

rule_logic.premise: Character does not eat or drink the full required amount of food or water
rule_logic.implication: Character suffers the effects of exhaustion
exceptions: Exhaustion caused by lack of food or water cannot be removed until the character eats and drinks the full required amount
rule_logic.description_text: Characters who don't eat or drink suffer the effects of exhaustion (see appendix PH-A). Exhaustion caused by lack of food or water can't be removed until the character eats and drinks the full required amount.

extracted_concepts.definition: The standard amount of food a character needs per day to remain healthy.

rule_logic.premise: Standard daily activity
rule_logic.implication: Character needs one pound of food per day
exceptions: Character can subsist on half rations, where eating half a pound of food counts as half a day without food
rule_logic.description_text: A character needs one pound of food per day and can make food last longer by subsisting on half rations. Eating half a pound of food in a day counts as half a day without food.
related_search_terms: how much food do I need

extracted_concepts.definition: The rule for determining when a character suffers exhaustion due to lack of food.

rule_logic.premise: Character goes without food for a number of days exceeding (3 + Constitution modifier, minimum 1 day)
rule_logic.implication: Character automatically suffers one level of exhaustion at the end of each day beyond that limit
rule_logic.description_text: A character can go without food for a number of days equal to 3 + his or her Constitution modifier (minimum 1). At the end of each day beyond that limit, a character automatically suffers one level of exhaustion.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition for resetting the count of days a character has gone without food.

rule_logic.premise: Character consumes a normal day of eating (full required amount of food)
rule_logic.implication: The count of days without food is reset to zero
rule_logic.description_text: A normal day of eating resets the count of days without food to zero.

extracted_concepts.definition: The standard amount of water a character needs per day to remain hydrated.

rule_logic.premise: Standard daily activity
rule_logic.implication: Character needs one gallon of water per day
exceptions: Character needs two gallons of water per day if the weather is hot
rule_logic.description_text: A character needs one gallon of water per day, or two gallons per day if the weather is hot.
related_search_terms: how much water do I need

extracted_concepts.definition: The rule for suffering exhaustion when consuming only half the required daily water.

rule_logic.premise: Character drinks only half the daily required amount of water
rule_logic.implication: Character must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion at the end of the day
rule_logic.description_text: A character who drinks only half that much water must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion at the end of the day.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Water Deprivation Exhaustion (Less Than Half Water)
extracted_concepts.definition: The rule for suffering exhaustion when consuming less than half the required daily water.

rule_logic.premise: Character has access to and drinks less than half the daily required amount of water
rule_logic.implication: Character automatically suffers one level of exhaustion at the end of the day
rule_logic.description_text: A character with access to even less water automatically suffers one level of exhaustion at the end of the day.

extracted_concepts.definition: An exception to the standard exhaustion level when a character is already exhausted and suffers from water deprivation.

rule_logic.premise: Character already has one or more levels of exhaustion AND Character suffers exhaustion from water deprivation (either half water or less than half water scenarios)
rule_logic.implication: Character takes two levels of exhaustion instead of one
rule_logic.description_text: If the character already has one or more levels of exhaustion, the character takes two levels in either case.

extracted_concepts.definition: A character's action to interact with an object that is straightforward to resolve without complex mechanics.

rule_logic.premise: Character attempts a simple interaction with an object (e.g., moving a lever)
rule_logic.implication: GM describes the outcome, if any
rule_logic.description_text: A character's interaction with objects in an environment is often simple to resolve in the game. The player tells the GM that his or her character is doing something, such as moving a lever, and the GM describes what, if anything, happens.

extracted_concepts.definition: Attempting to manipulate an object that is stuck, rusted, or otherwise difficult to move or activate.

rule_logic.premise: Character attempts to interact with an object that is stuck or difficult to move (e.g., a rusted lever)
rule_logic.implication: GM calls for a Strength check; DC is set by GM based on difficulty
rule_logic.description_text: If the lever is rusted in position, though, a character might need to force it. In such a situation, the GM might call for a Strength check to see whether the character can wrench the lever into place. The GM sets the DC for any such check based on the difficulty of the task.

extracted_concepts.definition: Specific damage types from which objects are inherently protected.

rule_logic.premise: An object is targeted by poison damage OR an object is targeted by psychic damage
rule_logic.implication: Object is immune to poison damage AND object is immune to psychic damage
rule_logic.description_text: Objects are immune to poison and psychic damage...

extracted_concepts.definition: How objects are affected by physical and magical attacks that are not poison or psychic.

rule_logic.premise: An object is targeted by damage types other than poison or psychic
rule_logic.implication: Object can be affected by physical and magical attacks much like creatures can
rule_logic.description_text: ...but otherwise they can be affected by physical and magical attacks much like creatures can.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Object Armor Class and Hit Points Determination
extracted_concepts.definition: The method by which an object's durability in combat is established.

rule_logic.premise: Determining an object's combat statistics (AC, HP)
rule_logic.implication: GM determines an object's Armor Class AND GM determines an object's hit points
rule_logic.description_text: The GM determines an object's Armor Class and hit points...

extracted_concepts.definition: The Game Master's ability to assign specific resistances or immunities to objects based on their nature or composition.

rule_logic.premise: An object's specific damage resistances or immunities need to be determined
rule_logic.implication: GM might decide that certain objects have resistance or immunity to certain kinds of attacks (e.g., hard to cut a rope with a club)
rule_logic.description_text: ...and might decide that certain objects have resistance or immunity to certain kinds of attacks. (It's hard to cut a rope with a club, for example.)

extracted_concepts.definition: The outcome when an object is required to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw.

rule_logic.premise: An object is required to make a Strength saving throw OR an object is required to make a Dexterity saving throw
rule_logic.implication: Object always fails Strength saving throws AND object always fails Dexterity saving throws
rule_logic.description_text: Objects always fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws...

extracted_concepts.definition: The outcome when an object is required to make a saving throw other than Strength or Dexterity.

rule_logic.premise: An effect requires an object to make a saving throw (other than Strength or Dexterity)
rule_logic.implication: Object is immune to effects that require other saves
rule_logic.description_text: ...and they are immune to effects that require other saves.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition under which an object is considered destroyed.

rule_logic.premise: An object drops to 0 hit points
rule_logic.implication: Object breaks
rule_logic.description_text: When an object drops to 0 hit points, it breaks.

extracted_concepts.definition: An alternative method for a character to destroy an object through sheer physical force.

rule_logic.premise: A character attempts to break an object using raw strength
rule_logic.implication: Character makes a Strength check; DC is set by GM
rule_logic.description_text: A character can also attempt a Strength check to break an object. The GM sets the DC for any such check.
